newsitem.title: ESTONIA: Estonian banks welcome stricter adequacy ratios.
newsitem.headline: Estonian banks welcome stricter adequacy ratios.

text.p: Big Estonian commercial banks welcomed a new, stricter capital adequacy ratio rule on Wednesday, saying it would be positive for banks and the economy as a whole.
Tallinna Pank board vice-chairman Targo Raus told Reuters that the new requirement would theoretically decrease risk in the sector but would not halt lending.
"All the bigger banks have been holding their capital adequacy ratio above 10 percent," he said.
"It is not going to harm economic growth but rather it will have a positive impact on it," Raus said.
"The banking sector will be safer and people will bring more money to bank deposits," he added.
Erkki Raasuke, head of interest rate products at Estonia's largest bank, Hansapank, welcomed the news.
"The news is fundamentally good for Hansapank in the long term as Hansapank's capital adequacy is always higher so it is very welcome," he said.
"The shift to 10 percent could have been done in a less visible manner and it could hurt the equities market," he added.
Uhispank vice-president Janek Maggi said the move is positive as it decreases the possibility to take risks.
"One can hold higher risks between eight and 10 percent," he added.
But he noted that as it diminished the possibilities to take risks, it also decreased the earnings opportunities for banks.
He also said that the bigger banks already have their capital adequacy ratio at 12 percent so the move means it will affect smaller banks more, Maggi added.
